text.tspan: Type I- achalasia with minimal esophageal pressure
Type II- achalasia with esophageal compression- more likely to respond to
botulinum toxin, pneumatic dilation, or Heller myotomy than others
Type III-achalasia with spasm. than type I or type II patients.
Primary achalasia can be associated with HLA-DQw1 antibodies to enteric
Primary achalasia may also be related to previous infection with HSV or
Secondary causes are also known as pseudoachalasia.
can result in a loss of intramural ganglion cells.
is the most common cause of pseudoachalasia either by direct
latter is v. suggestive for achalasia.
- this is usually in the range of 5 to 10 kg,
although profound weight loss can be seen.
over years- doesnt improve with dilatation).
Cancer-this is diagnosed an average of 14 years
Achalasia occurs at virtually any age, but
If progresses, the oesophagus becomes sigmoid

svg.text: Risk is too small to warrant surveillance.
